resources.string: The project is to design a smart phone app analyzing the indoor air concentration of formaldehyde: the users will expose the chemical sensor indoor, then take a picture through SmART-Form app. The app will recognize the color identity of chemical sensor and return the result of air concentration of formaldehyde. \n\n Shane
Enter a title for the test.

Instructions:

1.You should have a chemical badge along with the app. 
2.Open the app and select “New test”, name your test. 
3.Select the “Before” button and take a picture of the badge before exposure. 
4.Save your test and keep the badge still for 72hrs exposure. 
5.Select the “After” button and take a picture of the badge after exposure. 
6.Save your test and select “Data Survey”, complete the sampling survey. 
7.Complete the follow-up community testing surveys."
There are currently no tests to display.
%1$s: The test was created on %2$s. %3$s, and the result is %4$s.

COPYRIGHT:

SmartPhone App for Residential Testing of Formaldehyde (SmART-Form)

Department of Civil, Environmental and Geodetic Engineering

This is a consent form for your participation in this research study.


The purpose of this research project is to develop a low-cost and highly accurate technique for assessing domestic formaldehyde concentrations and is being conducted by Ohio State University in conjunction with the Public Laboratory for Open Technology and Science (Public Lab). Insights from citizen scientists and other relevant members of the public are key to developing the most robust and useable technology possible.


You are invited to participate in this research project because you are: A member of an environmental or citizen science organization (Public Lab, Global Community Monitor, or the Sierra Club’s formaldehyde campaign) A resident of Waycross, GA where the technology developed by this project will be first deployed.


Your participation in this research study is voluntary. You may choose not to participate. If you decide to participate in this research survey, you may withdraw at any time. If you decide not to participate in this study or if you withdraw from participating at any time, there will be no penalty or loss of benefits that the participant is entitled to. You may skip any questions you do not wish to answer. If you want do not wish to complete this survey just close your browser.


The procedure involves filling an online survey that will take approximately 20 minutes. Your responses will be confidential and we do not collect identifying information such as your name, email address or IP address. The survey questions will be about your interest in testing for airborne formaldehyde, how we should build the software and hardware for this technology to best suit your needs, and reflections on past community science studies (if applicable).


We will work to make sure that no one sees your survey responses without approval. But, because we are using the Internet, there is a chance that someone could access your online responses without permission. In some cases, this information could be used to identify you. Your data will be protected with a code to reduce the risk that other people can view the responses. We will do our best to keep your information confidential. All data is stored in a password protected electronic format. To help protect your confidentiality, the surveys will not contain information that will personally identify you. The results of this study will be used for scholarly, technical development, public education purposes only and may be shared with Ohio State University representatives.


For questions, concerns, or complaints about the study, or you feel you have been harmed as a result of study participation, you may contact Karen Dannemiller at 614-292-4031.


For questions about your rights as a participant in this study or to discuss other study-related concerns or complaints with someone who is not part of the research team, you may contact Ms. Sandra Meadows in the Office of Responsible Research Practices at 1-800-678-6251.This research has been reviewed according to Ohio State University IRB procedures for research involving human subjects.


Please print a copy of this consent form for your records, if you so desire.


ELECTRONIC CONSENT: Please select your choice below.


Clicking on the "agree" button below indicates that:

*You have ready the above information

*You voluntarily agree to participate

*You are at least 18 years of age


If you do not wish to participate in the research study, please decline participation by clicking on the "disagree" button.

This is an user experience survey.


 You will be asked for few questions about this app.


 Please share your comments or suggestions with us.
Please match the highlighted triangle with the colored area approximately

ABOUT US


 The purpose of this research project is to design a smartphone app to allow community scientists to determine the formaldehyde concentrations in their homes or in outdoor air.


 We would like to receive feedback from you about your experience using the app. Your participation is voluntary and all questions are voluntary.


 Contributing your data will help us!


 Email: dannemiller.70@osu.edu


 Phone: 504-233-0539


 Website: u.osu.edu/smartform
What does my formaldehyde level mean?

The exact healthy levels for indoor formaldehyde isn’t set. Here are some current recommendations: 

• 8 ppb for indoor at home 
(Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR) chronic minimum risk level) 
• 40 ppb for indoor at home over 8 hours 
(Health Canada's Residential Indoor Air Quality Guideline for 8 hours) 
• 16 ppb for workplace over 8 hours 
(NIOSH Recommended Exposure Limit (REL) for 8 hours) 
• 750 ppb (500 ppb action level) for workplace danger limit: 	(OSHA workplace limit) 

Here are two ways to cut down indoor formaldehyde levels: 

STEP 1 Remove or stop the source. Common sources include: 
• Smoking 
• Pressed wood products (plywood/particleboard) 
• Adhesives used in new carpet 
• Certain types of new hardwood flooring 
• Gas stove 
• Other gas appliances 
• Use of nail polish 
• Use of adhesives/glues 
• Use of paints 
• New indoor paint 
• All-purpose cleaner (certain types) 
• Window cleaner (certain types) 

Other steps might include: 

• Not smoking indoors 
• Removing pressed wood products (plywood/particleboard) 
• When possible, go outdoors if you must use paints/adhesives/glues
ail polish 
• Using a vent fan with gas appliances 
• Using no-VOC or low-VOC indoor paint 
• Changing to natural cleaning products or soap and water 

STEP 2: Increase ventilation. 

This only applies if the outdoor air has low formaldehyde concentrations, which it does in most cases. 
• Open windows (this works best by opening windows on two sides of the house for a cross-breeze) 
• Window fans (drawing outdoor air into the house) 

Other steps might include: 

• Home air filters and purifiers - Activated carbon filters are the best for removing formaldehyde, but they may not work for long because they get saturated quickly. Otherwise, home air filters and purifiers don’t usually work well on changing indoor formaldehyde levels. Household plants can also improve overall indoor air quality, but their ability to reduce formaldehyde is likely very small. 

Indoor Formaldehyde and Health 

Formaldehyde can cause irritation to the skin and lining of the eyes, nose, mouth, throat, and airways. This irritation might worsen the symptoms for people with conditions like respiratory diseases and allergies. Being around higher levels of formaldehyde for long periods of time has also been linked to some cancers. 

More information can be found at www.epa.gov/formaldehyde
